Changes in Weekly Macro Themes & Composites

Weekly comparison of macro-theme and composite assessmentsusing integrated US and global macro regimes.

As of 2025-12-05

Weekly Macro Theme Change Report

Weekly Macro Theme Change Report

Comparing last week’s macro-theme and composite assessments with the latest updates.

Executive Summary

The overall cross-asset macro landscape remains broadly consistent with the prior week's assessment. Key US macro themes continue to reflect a late-cycle deceleration, characterized by persistent disinflationary pressures and a softening labor market, operating under a net expansionary liquidity impulse. Global conditions maintain a narrative of resilient industrial demand, counterbalanced by defensive precious metals positioning and ongoing commodity supply-side stress.

There have been no material shifts in the primary macro-theme regimes or composite overviews this week. The prevailing narrative suggests a continuation of the established trends and balances of risks, highlighting stability in the market's current interpretation of macroeconomic conditions.

  • Headline US macro regime: Consistent with Late-Cycle Deceleration with Emerging Fragilities.
  • Headline Global macro regime: Consistent with Resilient Industrial Demand Amidst Defensive Positioning and Mixed Forward Cycle Signals.
  • Inflation vs. Growth balance: US inflation continues to signal COOL, while growth exhibits deceleration, remaining broadly unchanged.
  • Liquidity & Monetary vs. Credit Conditions: Liquidity remains expansionary, and credit conditions are predominantly neutral, with no material shifts.
  • Labour market vs. Demand signals: US labor market continues cooling, aligning with softening demand trends.
  • Cross-asset positioning & sentiment: Systemic volatility remains normalized, with persistent concentrated tensions.

1. US Macro Themes: Weekly Change

The US macro themes, encompassing growth, inflation, liquidity, credit, and labor, have exhibited no significant changes in their reported regimes or underlying characterizations this week. The narrative points to a continued late-cycle deceleration, disinflationary environment, and softening labor market, underpinned by an expansionary liquidity stance. Credit conditions remain broadly neutral, albeit with noted latent fragilities.

US Growth & Business Cycle Late-Cycle Deceleration with Emerging Fragilities Late-Cycle Deceleration with Emerging Fragilities Unchanged Broadly unchanged in narrative and regime characterization.
US Inflation & Price Dynamics COOL (disinflation/deflation risk) COOL (disinflation/deflation risk) Unchanged Broadly unchanged in narrative and regime characterization.
US Liquidity & Monetary Conditions Liquidity-Driven Expansion with Neutral Real Rates Liquidity-Driven Expansion with Neutral Real Rates Unchanged Broadly unchanged in narrative and regime characterization.
US Credit Conditions Predominantly Neutral Predominantly Neutral Unchanged Broadly unchanged in narrative and regime characterization.
US Labour Market Cooling at the Margin, but Overall Neutral Cooling at the Margin, but Overall Neutral Unchanged Broadly unchanged in narrative and regime characterization.

2. Global Macro Themes: Weekly Change

Global macro themes, including growth cycles, inflation & FX dynamics, trade & demand, and cross-asset positioning, have also shown no discernible shifts in their reported regimes or high-level interpretations over the past week. Resilient industrial demand continues to be offset by defensive positioning, while a weakening USD and commodity supply stress remain central to the global narrative.

Global Theme Previous Regime Current Regime Direction of Change Key Weekly Change
Global Growth & Economic Cycles Resilient Industrial Demand Amidst Defensive Positioning and Mixed Forward Cycle Signals Resilient Industrial Demand Amidst Defensive Positioning and Mixed Forward Cycle Signals Unchanged Broadly unchanged in narrative and regime characterization.

Cross-Asset Positioning & Sentiment Normalizing systemic volatility with specific tensions Normalizing systemic volatility with specific tensions Unchanged Broadly unchanged in narrative and regime characterization.

3. Composite Macro Overviews: Weekly Change

Both the US Macro Overview and Global Macro Overview composites remain consistent with their prior week's assessments. No significant changes in overall macro risk or headline labels have been observed, indicating a stable and persistent interpretation of the consolidated US and global macroeconomic backdrops.

Composite Previous Regime Current Regime Direction of Change Key Weekly Change
US Macro Overview Late-Cycle Deceleration with Emerging Fragilities Late-Cycle Deceleration with Emerging Fragilities Unchanged Broadly unchanged in narrative and regime characterization.
Global Macro Overview Resilient Industrial Demand Amidst Defensive Positioning and Mixed Forward Cycle Signals Resilient Industrial Demand Amidst Defensive Positioning and Mixed Forward Cycle Signals Unchanged Broadly unchanged in narrative and regime characterization.

4. Cross-Theme Interpretation

The consistent readings across US, Global, and Composite themes suggest a stable macro narrative week-over-week. The US economy continues to be characterized by moderating growth and easing inflation, with a softening labor market being cushioned by an accommodative Federal Reserve easing bias. Globally, industrial resilience persists, but remains juxtaposed with cautious financial positioning and ongoing commodity supply challenges. No new divergences or significant tensions have emerged this week, reinforcing the established macro regime interpretation.

5. Forward Risks & Watchpoints

Key Upside / Resilience Factors

  • Continued core manufacturing momentum potentially broadening into wider business investment, offsetting consumer deceleration.
  • A sustained and orderly liquidity injection from Fed operations, supported by ongoing M2 growth, could provide a supportive impulse.
  • Stabilization or incremental improvement in US labor market metrics, consistent with a soft landing scenario.
  • Persistent anchoring of inflation expectations, allowing the Fed's easing bias to proceed without reigniting price pressures.

Key Downside / Deterioration Risks

  • A sharper-than-anticipated US growth slowdown or broad deterioration in the labor market, particularly if unemployment accelerates.
  • The Fed's easing bias proving insufficient to counter a significant economic deceleration, or inflation remaining stickier than currently anticipated.
  • Wider credit spreads, increased consumer loan delinquencies, or an escalation of systemic stress indicators, highlighting underlying fragilities.
  • Further weakening of consumer spending or an unwinding of concentrated speculative positions in major equity indices.
  • A reversal of the current weakening USD trend or an unexpected re-acceleration of commodity prices, potentially undermining global disinflationary narratives.
